  • What Twitter was, and what it is now

    Jean MacDonald:

    I have several friends in ‚Äúreal life‚Äù who started as Twitter buddies. But over the years, Twitter has become something I don‚Äôt recognize anymore, a place where hate and intolerance and crass commercialism have found a welcoming home.

    As a side note, a nice insight into understanding micro.blog as a Twitter user‚Äîhow they‚Äôre same in some ways, and how they‚Äôre different.

    Her Twitter experience though is not far away from mine; some of my closest friendships & collaborations have their origins on the network, but ‚Ä¶ here we are now.

    Jean doesn‚Äôt get into this much but a long-standing problem with Twitter is how they‚Äôve stifled third party development, over, over and over again. I mean, even a service like LinkedIn doesn‚Äôt‚Äîwell, can‚Äôt‚Äîreally integrate with Twitter.

    The ‚Äòphilosophy‚Äô of increasingly closing off the network to the outside world or the open Web at large has been seeping into other aspects of Twitter‚Äôs culture as an organization & a platform. The last few real Twitter apps are now bending under this weight.

    Considering Facebook isn‚Äôt in a particularly great place currently either, hello to an free-er, open-er Web. And hello, Micro.blog.

  • Massaging egos #facebook

    Zeynep Tufekci, writing for WIRED:

    ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs Time to Make Our Privacy Tools Easier to Find‚Äù, the company announced without a hint of irony‚Äîor any other kind of hint‚Äîthat Zuckerberg had promised to do just that in the ‚Äúcoming few weeks‚Äù eight full years ago. On the company blog, Facebook‚Äôs chief privacy editor wrote that instead of being ‚Äúspread across nearly 20 different screens‚Äù (why were they ever spread all over the place?), the controls would now finally be in one place.

    It‚Äôs a long read but a great piece that highlights the right things. Any other company would have lost trust years ago but Facebook continues to enjoy the advantage of the ‚Äògravity‚Äô effect of having 2 billion users.

    My co-host Partha made a super important point last week:

    These products have been made by the same people who lived with the same sort of theory that [our generation] grew up with [‚Ä¶] they understand the importance of this privacy and they‚Äôve been building on top of this to try and massage the egos of all the newer generations [‚Ä¶] to try and make sure they‚Äôre comfortable about it.

    The more I think about this, the more spot-on this is. People who watched‚Äîushered in, even‚Äîthe social media era and understand the privacy implications could have gone about it in two ways: ensure that even those who do not understand this are protected, or help transition the vary ones into being more comfortable about sharing. Facebook has gone the latter way too often that it‚Äôs now part of its core, making it impossible to be anything else.

  • #Privacy iOS users, Settings ‚Üí Privacy is your friend. Review & turn things off for apps that don‚Äôt need content they have access to. Turn on Advertising ‚Üí Limit Ad Tracking, which stops providers from targeting ads to you (you can reset this ad ID if the setting was off).

  • Facebook: ‚ÄòEveryone‚Äôs doing it‚Äô

    Sean Gallagher, writing for Ars Technica:

    In response to an email inquiry by Ars about this data gathering, a Facebook spokesperson replied, ‚ÄúThe most important part of apps and services that help you make connections is to make it easy to find the people you want to connect with. So, the first time you sign in on your phone to a messaging or social app, it‚Äôs a widely used practice to begin by uploading your phone contacts.‚Äù

    A widely used practice is something Facebook could have taken a stand on, eons ago, and led the industry, rather hiding under its cover.

    As much as the headlines about Facebook having a bad week will continue, it‚Äôs amazing how unchecked the whole system was:

    If you granted permission to read contacts during Facebook‚Äôs installation on Android a few versions ago‚Äîspecifically before Android 4.1 (Jelly Bean)‚Äîthat permission also granted Facebook access to call and message logs by default. The permission structure was changed in the Android API in version 16. But Android applications could bypass this change if they were written to earlier versions of the API, so Facebook API could continue to gain access to call and SMS data by specifying an earlier Android SDK version. Google deprecated version 4.0 of the Android API in October 2017‚Äîthe point at which the latest call metadata in Facebook users‚Äô data was found.

    The issue with such far reaching applications and OS‚Äô is that there aren‚Äôt‚Äîand are unlikely to be anytime soon‚Äîoverarching regulations that can manage these issues. Even if the US or the EU has stringent privacy regulations that will allow them to penalize Facebook‚Äôs entities within their jurisdiction, that‚Äôs as far as they‚Äôd be able to go.

    Six months down the road, where will this situation be? Will Facebook brazen it out through via heres-another-setting-under-privacy-settings? That can be the only real indicator.
